p.s: In the following lines, the poem Sonnet 65 written by William Shakespeare in the 16th century, is going to be analyzed.
The sonnet was published during the elizabethanElizabethan time in England and deals with the transitoriness of youth, love and beauty because of the immortality of time.
The sonnet consists of, as well as every sonnet of Shakespeare, 14 lines which are divided into three quatrains with four lines each and a last doptain with two lines.
In addition to that, the rhyme scheme is also similar to Shakespeare's other sonnets.
The rhyme is ABAB CDCD EFEF GG and is paired with iambic parameter as the meter.
The last two lines bring up an explanation for the first 12 lines.
In the first lines of the sonnet, Shakespeare right about the nature's mortality which destroys its beauty and power.
After that the poet asks how beauty could resist the power of time.
Later he recognizes that nothing, no matter how strong something might be, could resist the decay of time.
The last quatrain consistconsists of the question, if there is something that can hold back the time from killing the beauty of the earth.
The last two lines bring up a solution which consists of the poet saying that even if nothing can beat the mortality of time his love will never end because he expressed it through his writings.
As sad in the introduction, the main topic of Sonnet 65 is the mortality of time which leaves no chance for mortal aspects like love, beauty or youth.
